results.abstract: Ilia and Lilia Borovsky, Russian emigres, are dance teachers at Royal Ballroom in Dobbs Ferry, NY; they say in recent years many ballroom dancers have left Russia and come to United States, where they can pursue their dancing and teach it to amateurs at studios like Royal Ballroom; photos (M)

headline.main: The View From/Dobbs Ferry; Ballroom Dance Pizazz From Russian Emigres

results.snippet: WHEN she was a little girl in the city of Baku in what was then the Soviet Union, Lilia Borovski told herself stories about becoming a dancer and a princess. The princess part did not materialize, but she and her husband, Ilia Borovski, could be seen...
results.lead_paragraph: WHEN she was a little girl in the city of Baku in what was then the Soviet Union, Lilia Borovski told herself stories about becoming a dancer and a princess. The princess part did not materialize, but she and her husband, Ilia Borovski, could be seen as royalty of sorts. Still in their early 20's, they are well known in the world of competitive ballroom dancing, having won dozens of international competitions doing everything from the stately waltz to the flashy Argentine tango. Last year, they moved from Moscow to the United States to broaden their opportunities. Earlier this winter, they became teachers at Royal Ballroom, a studio that opened here this month. Their reputations in Russia had been solid, they said, but here in America, they felt they could soar as far as their fancy footwork could carry them.
